title: Software
text:
bootUR

R package for bootstrap unit root tests
The R package bootUR, co-authored with Ines Wilms, is available on CRAN and GitHub. In this package we implement several bootstrap unit root tests, both for univariate and multivariate time series, including (but not limited to) all the unit root tests proposed in my papers. For details see the website or the accompanying JSS paper.
The package encompasses all code available below that relates to unit root testing in a coherent and user-friendly way. As a consequence, all bootstrap unit root testing codes below are not updated anymore, as I will only keep the package up to date.
Questions and comments on the bootUR package are welcome via the GitHub page. To cite the package in your research, use the command citation("bootUR") in R.



desla

R package for desparsified lasso inference for time series
The R package desla, developed by Robert Adamek, is available on CRAN and GitHub. This package allows for inference in high-dimensional time series models via the desparsified lasso as proposed in the papers “Lasso inference for high-dimensional time series” and “Local projection inference in high dimensions”.



specs

R package for penalized single-equation error-correction models
The R package specs, developed by Etienne Wijler, is available on CRAN and GitHub. In this package the Single-Equation Penalized Error-Correction Selector (SPECS) from the paper “An automated approach towards sparse single-equation cointegration modelling” is implemented. The data from the paper are also included.



HDGCvar

R package for Granger causality testing in high-dimensional vector autoregressive models
The R package HDGCvar, developed by Luca Margaritella, is available on GitHub. This package allows for testing Granger causality in high-dimensional vector autoregressive models (VARs) as proposed in the papers “Granger causality testing in high-dimensional VARs: a Post-Double-Selection procedure” and “Inference in non-stationary high-dimensional VARs”.



PAGFL

R package for estimating latent group structures in panel data
The R package PAGFL, developed by Paul Haimerl, is available on CRAN and GitHub. This package allows for estimating latent group structures by implementing the pairwise adaptive group fused Lasso (PAGFL) proposed by Mehrabani (2023) and its extendsion to time-varying coefficient functions as proposed in the paper “Estimation of Latent Group Structures in Time-Varying Panel Data Models”.



Transmission Channel Analysis

Toolbox for estimating dynamic transmission channels
The TCA toolbox developed by Enrico Wegner allows for estimating transmission channels as proposed in the paper “Transmission Channel Analysis in Dynamic Models”. There is both a Julia version and Matlab version available.



Individual Codes

Scripts not available in a package






Note



The codes are provided without any warranty whatsoever and will not be updated except to fix bugs. All codes are provided under a GPL 2 or later license unless stated otherwise. To cite the codes, please cite the relevant papers and provide a link to this website.

MATLAB toolbox for the WIMP method developed in the paper “Inference for impulse responses under model uncertainty”. The code and data in the toolbox allow for replication of the WIMP confidence bands for all the identification schemes used in the empirical study in the paper.

1 The zip-files with Gauss codes contain two files: a ‘.gss’ file with the original Gauss code, and a ‘.src’ file with modifications of that code such that it can be run in OxGauss.2 The R code has been tested to give (almost) identical output to the Gauss output using a limited number of datasets.

The methods covered by these codes are all available in the bootUR package, the use of which is strongly recommended. The codes provided here will not be updated anymore.

The code includes the lag length selection methods developed in the paper “Lag length selection for unit root tests in the presence of nonstationary volatility”.


GAUSS code and R code for the bootstrap sequential quantile tests developed in the paper “Bootstrap sequential tests to determine the order of integration of individual units in a time series panel”.


GAUSS code for the bootstrap union tests developed in the paper “Bootstrap union tests for unit roots in the presence of nonstationary volatility”.

title: Teaching
text:
Current Teaching
I mostly teach in the BSc and MSc programmes in Econometrics and Operations Research, but also in the BSc Economics and Business Economics and the MSc Economic and Financial Research.
My teaching entails both course coordination (including lecturing and tutoring) and thesis supervsion. I am also currently the programme coordinator for the MSc Econometrics and Operations Research programme and the corresponding pre-master’s programme.
Currently I teach the following courses:

EBC4218 – Big Data Econometrics MSc EOR + EFR
EBS4043 – Computational Research Skills MSc EOR
EBS4044 – Computational Research Skills MSc EFR
EBC2107 – Mathematical Statistics BSc EOR
EBC2011 – Quantitative Methods 3 - Statistics BSc EBE
EBS4024 – Writing a Referee Report MSc EFR



EOR: Econometrics and Operations Research  EFR: Economic and Financial Research  EBE: Economics and Business Economics


Online Education Materials

Lecture Notes on the Bootstrap
For use in my courses I wrote introductory notes about the bootstrap. They are available here under a CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 license. I hope they prove to be useful for studying or teaching the bootstrap, and I would be happy to hear your feedback about them (both things you like and don’t like).


Time Series Analysis and Forecasting - BlueCourses
Ines Wilms, Nalan Basturk, Etienne Wijler and I have developed the online course Time Series Analysis and Forecasting, which teaches the essentials of modern time series analysis with R. It is hosted by BlueCourses, which transfers part of the fee to organizations protecting the oceans.

title: Stephan Smeekes
text:
Welcome to the Personal Website of Stephan Smeekes
I am a Professor of Econometrics in the Department of Quantitative Economics at the School of Business and Economics, Maastricht University.
My research focuses on the statistical analysis of time series data - developing methods at the intersection of econometrics, statistics, and data science. I specialize in modeling complex dynamic systems involving multiple time series, with a strong emphasis on uncertainty quantification, often leveraging bootstrap techniques.
I apply these tools to explore causality, trends, forecasting, and risk measurement across a range of fields - from macroeconomics and finance to climate, environmental and medical applications.
I am passionate about inter- and transdisciplinary research that forges new connections between fields, aiming for both academic insight and real-world impact. I am open to collaborations that challenge conventional boundaries.
In parallel, I am committed to teaching statistics, econometrics, and computational data science at all levels - from undergraduate to postgraduate.
I led the NWO Veni project Bootstrap Methods for Time-Varying Processes and the NWO Vidi project Inference for High-Dimensional Econometric Time Series, and was a member of the Dutch Young Academy (De Jonge Akademie).
On this website you can find information about me, my research and teaching, as well as software and code to implement several of the econometric and statistical techniques I developed. Finally I collected some useful links and more.
